channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: For Netanyahu, like Trump, Only ‘Fraud’ Can Explain His Defeat
item.description: Israel’s democratic transition is set for Sunday, but nothing is certain amid the prime minister’s scorched-earth campaign to wreck his opponents’ coalition.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel speaking at a Jerusalem ceremony on Sunday to honor pandemic medical teams. Mr. Netanyahu, facing a loss of power after 12 years, is ferociously resisting that outcome.

item.title: Hundreds Arrested in Global Sting Using App Run by F.B.I.
item.description: Global law enforcement officials revealed a three-year operation in which they said they had intercepted over 20 million messages. Hundreds of arrests were made in more than a dozen countries.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang, Elian Peltier and Alan Feuer
item.media:description: The Australian Federal Police arresting a suspect as part of a multinational operation.

item.title: The Mayor, the Teacher and a Fight Over a ‘Lost Territory’ of France
item.description: A battle erupted after a high-school teacher said that Islamists had taken over the city of Trappes, a view vigorously countered by the mayor, sharpening a national debate over French identity.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Cyril Zannettacci for The New York Times
item.media:description: Trappes gave birth to some of the country’s brightest entertainment and sports stars, but also saw about 70 of its youths leave for jihad to Syria and Iraq.

item.title: Kamala Harris, With Blunt Language on Border, Forges Immigration Image
item.description: The vice president concluded her first trip abroad, a high-stakes trip to Mexico and Guatemala during which she took on the politically volatile issue.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris and President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico in Mexico City on Tuesday.

item.title: Israel’s Parliament to Vote on New Government on Sunday
item.description: If lawmakers approve a fragile new coalition government, Israel will be led by someone other than Benjamin Netanyahu for the first time in 12 years.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, center, and his party have vowed to try to peel off wavering members of the prospective coalition.

item.title: Make China 'Lovable,' Xi Said. But Don't Expect Softening.
item.description: Xi Jinping’s remarks to top Communist Party leaders suggest Beijing will focus on courting allies rather than easing its rhetoric against the U.S. and Europe.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Keith Bradsher
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, at the National People’s Congress in March. He said last week that China needed a more “lovable and respectable” image.

item.title: Mass Graves at Residential Schools in Canada: What to Know
item.description: The discovery of the remains of 215 children at the site of a defunct boarding school in British Columbia has rekindled discussion of a sinister time in Canada’s history.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Children’s shoes and toys were placed in front of the former Kamloops Indian Residential School in British Columbia after the remains of 215 children, some as young as 3, were found at the site this past week.

item.title: Ratko Mladic Loses Final Appeal in Genocide Conviction
item.description: The confirmation of the verdict against the Bosnian Serb former commander, convicted in 2017 of crimes against humanity for his role in the Balkan wars, closes a grim chapter in European history.
item.dc:creator: Marlise Simons and Marc Santora
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia
item.media:credit: UN International Residual Mechanism for Criminal Tribunals/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Ratko Mladic in court in The Hague in August for his appeal against a life sentence.

item.title: U.N. Security Council Recommends António Guterres for a Second Term
item.description: The Council’s recommendation basically assures the Portuguese statesman’s tenure as secretary general and extends the history of male-only stewardship of the United Nations since its 1945 founding.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone
item.media:description: Secretary General António Guterres has received praise for steering the United Nations through the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Man Slaps Macron During Visit to Southern France
item.description: Two people were arrested after a man slapped the French president as he was approaching a small crowd, prompting condemnation of the attack across the political spectrum.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France speaking to journalists during a visit to a hospitality school in Tain l’Hermitage, France.

item.title: London Police Officer Pleads Guilty to Rape and Kidnap of Sarah Everard
item.description: Wayne Couzens admitted to charges of rape and kidnapping of the 33-year-old marketing executive, whose killing in March touched off national anger at male violence against women.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Messages of support and flowers left in memory of Sarah Everard in London in March.

item.title: Senate Passes Bill to Bolster Competitiveness With China
item.description: The wide margin of support reflected a sense of urgency among lawmakers in both parties about shoring up the technological and industrial capacity of the United States to counter Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: The legislation was a collaboration between Senator Chuck Schumer, the majority leader, and Senator Todd Young, Republican of Indiana.

item.title: Truck Attack That Killed a Muslim Family in Canada Was Planned
item.description: The police in London, Ontario, say that a 20-year-old driver planned the killings and picked the family because of its faith.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Geoff Robins/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Police officers looking on Monday for evidence where a pickup truck killed four members of a Muslim family in London, Ontario, a day earlier.

item.title: A U.N. Declaration on Ending AIDS Should Have Been Easy. It Wasn’t.
item.description: Even with U.N.’s previous goals unmet, delegates tried to water down provisions regarding protections for vulnerable populations and patents for essential drugs.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: A patient with AIDS receiving her medication in Haiti in 2009.

item.title: Emma Coronel Aispuro Set to Plead Guilty to Helping Run Drug Empire
item.description: Emma Coronel Aispuro is scheduled to appear in court in Washington on Thursday to admit her role in her husband’s criminal activities.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Stephen Speranza for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emma Coronel Aispuro, the wife of the drug lord El Chapo, was taken into custody in February outside Washington after a nearly two-year investigation by American law enforcement officials.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Rising prices in China.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: A port in Lianyungang, Jiangsu Province, last year. Beijing has discouraged steelmakers from raising prices.

item.title: Pilots in India Seek Better Payouts for Colleagues Killed by Covid
item.description: Air India pilots had their salaries reduced during the pandemic, a union says, and many came to India’s aid when people and vaccines needed to be transported, though they were not vaccinated themselves.
item.dc:creator: Karan Deep Singh
item.media:description: An Air India aircraft delivering vaccines to Nepal in January.

item.title: Japan Sushi Bar Rents Conveyor Belts for Takeout
item.description: To survive a prolonged state of emergency, restaurants in Japan are getting creative.
item.dc:creator: Hisako Ueno and Shashank Bengali
item.media:credit: Andy Haslam for The New York Times
item.media:description: A sushi bar with a conveyor belt in Kanazawa, Japan.

item.title: An Investment With a Big Return
item.description: Alarmed by China’s rise, the Senate is on the verge of increasing research funding to help American companies.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: A semiconductor factory in Nantong, China.

item.title: Widespread Internet Outage Affects Major Websites
item.description: The sites of the British government, The New York Times and Twitter were among those that were briefly inaccessible for some users.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross and Adam Satariano
item.media:description: The British government’s main website was offline during the outage.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: A tense summer for Northern Ireland.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the loyalist community attend a protest march against the trade border between Northern Ireland and Britain.

item.title: In Guatemala, Harris Tells Undocumented to Stay Away From U.S. Border
item.description: In her first foreign trip as vice president, Kamala Harris promoted economic development and anti-corruption efforts, trying to stem the northward flow of migrants.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris with President Alejandro Giammattei of Guatemala on Monday in Guatemala City.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: India’s revamped vaccine efforts.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times

item.title: Boko Haram Leader Really Did Kill Himself, Audio Message Says
item.description: A notorious terrorist leader in Nigeria who kidnapped schoolgirls in Chibok has blown himself up, according to a new audio recording attributed to the head of a rival extremist group.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:description: A still image from a video released in 2014 showing a man who American officials believe was the Boko Haram leader, Abubakar Shekau.

item.title: A House Divided: A Palestinian, a Settler and the Struggle for East Jerusalem
item.description: Efforts to force Palestinians from Sheikh Jarrah set the stage for the recent Gaza war. A similar dynamic looms in a nearby district.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nasser Rajabi and his mother, in the doorway below, share a house in East Jerusalem with Jewish settlers.

item.title: New Dinosaur Species Is Australia’s Largest, Researchers Say
item.description: Australotitan cooperensis, a long-necked herbivore from the Cretaceous period, is estimated to have weighed 70 tons, measured two stories tall and extended the length of a basketball court.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Jett
item.media:description: A rendering of the Australotitan cooperensis, a new species of dinosaur. Researchers in Australia announced their discovery on Monday.

item.title: India to Take Over Vaccine Program From States Amid Criticism
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi also said shots would be free for all those over 18.
item.dc:creator: Karan Deep Singh
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: A health worker inoculated a man with dose of Covishield vaccine at health center of Sultanpur village in Uttar Pradesh, India, on Friday.

item.title: Northern Ireland, Strained by Brexit, Braces for Marching Season
item.description: Brexit has inflamed sectarian passions to a degree not seen since the 1998 Good Friday Agreement.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: Union Jacks this month outside a home in Sandy Row, a predominantly Protestant community in southern Belfast, the Northern Irish capital. Most residents of Sandy Row staunchly favor remaining in the United Kingdom.

item.title: In Mexico Election, López Obrador’s Grip on Congress Slips
item.description: Early results of midterm elections suggested that Andrés Manuel López Obrador’s coalition would not obtain the supermajority needed to push through his ambitious agenda.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Oscar Lopez
item.media:description: Voters in Mexico’s midterm elections dealt a setback to President Andrés Manuel López Obrador’s ambitious plans to change the country.

item.title: David Dushman, Soviet Soldier Who Helped Liberate Auschwitz, Dies at 98
item.description: Mr. Dushman is believed to have been the last surviving liberator of the camp. He went on to become a decorated fencer.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: David Dushman at the Russian War Memorial in Berlin in 2015.

item.title: The Dangerous Delta Variant
item.description: Covid cases are rising in Britain — and U.S. trends may soon follow.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: A line outside a vaccination center in London on Saturday.

item.title: South May See Summer Covid Surge as Vaccination Rates Lag
item.description: In 15 states, including Arkansas, the Carolinas, Georgia and Louisiana, about half of adults or fewer have received a vaccine dose.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez, Lazaro Gamio and Amy Schoenfeld Walker
item.media:description: At a vaccination site in Birmingham, Ala., last month. About half of adults in Alabama have had a first vaccine dose.

item.title: Living on the Margins, ‘Surfing’ on the Buses
item.description: In the Brazilian city of Olinda, a group of thrill seekers has taken up an illegal and death-defying hobby: riding on the outside of public buses.
item.dc:creator: Victor Moriyama

item.title: From Doomsday Preppers to Doomsday Plotters
item.description: Far-right movements have long dreamed of a moment that ends society as we’ve known it. Now, experts say, so-called accelerationist thinking is proliferating in ways that could destabilize democracy.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub and Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Reichstag, which houses the German Parliament in Berlin. Extremists have long spoken of “Day X” — a moment when Germany’s social order would collapse and they would rise.

item.title: Rome Gets Its First Pizza Vending Machine. Will Romans Bite?
item.description: In a city with no shortage of pizza — or self-appointed food critics — an entrepreneur is betting on diners with a sense of adventure.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Checking out the final product from Rome’s first automated pizza vending machine. It mixes and shapes the dough, spreads toppings and cooks the pizza in three minutes.

item.title: Peek at Broadway Comeback: Times Event With "Me and the Sky"
item.description: When The Times staged a musical number for its live event series, the performance served as a sneak preview of a theater world preparing for takeoff.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.media:credit: ACMN for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zoe Gertz, right, performing the number “Me and the Sky” from the musical “Come From Away.”

item.title: Senate Poised to Pass Huge Industrial Policy Bill to Counter China
item.description: The broad support for the bill highlights how competition with Beijing is one of the few issues that can still unite both political parties.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Catie Edmondson, David McCabe and Thomas Kaplan
item.media:description: A semiconductor factory in Beijing. Congress is poised to fund investments in semiconductor manufacturing.

item.title: Train Crash in Pakistan Kills Dozens
item.description: Most of the passengers on an express train were asleep when it derailed and its cars fell across the track into the path of another.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood
item.media:description: A video image of one of the express trains after a collision in Ghotki, Pakistan, on Monday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: A warning about incitement in Israel.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Israeli security officers deploy during a protest in support of arrested Palestinian activist siblings Mona and Muhammad el-Kurd, in front of a police station in Israeli-annexed east Jerusalem, on June 6, 2021.

item.title: German Conservatives Win Last State Election Before National Vote
item.description: The contest in an eastern state, a stronghold of the Alternative for Germany, had been closely watched for signs of the far-right party’s appeal, which dipped slightly.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: Reiner Haseloff, the premier of Germany’s Saxony-Anhalt state, as results in the regional elections were released on Sunday.

item.title: C.I.A. Scrambles for New Approach in Afghanistan
item.description: The rapid withdrawal of U.S. troops has left the agency seeking ways to maintain its intelligence-gathering, war-fighting and counterterrorism operations in the country.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Afghan soldier flying over Helmand Province last month. Recent C.I.A. and military intelligence reports on Afghanistan have been increasingly pessimistic, highlighting gains by the Taliban.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Tension in Israel ahead of key vote.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Naftali Bennett, who would be prime minister first if the coalition comes to power, speaks at Israel’s parliament.

item.title: British Tourists Rush to Return From Portugal as Deadline Looms
item.description: Thousands of British tourists paid extra to rebook early return flights. British Airways and other airlines added flight capacity to help bring them home.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder and Katie Thomas
item.media:description: British tourists and residents lining up to return to Britain from the airport in Faro, in Portugal’s Algarve region, on Saturday.

item.title: T.B. Joshua, Nigerian Celebrity Megachurch Pastor, Dies at 57
item.description: Mr. Joshua had millions of followers, including top politicians and sports stars. But he was dogged by controversy over his products, his prophecies and events in which church members died.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:credit: Pius Utomi Ekpei/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Temitope Balogun Joshua, the founder of the Synagogue Church of All Nations, in 2015.

item.title: Nicaragua’s Democracy Hangs by Thread as Crackdown Deepens
item.description: Under President Daniel Ortega, the country is a step away from becoming a one-party state. Money-laundering charges against his main rival have heightened concerns.
item.dc:creator: Yubelka Mendoza and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: President Daniel Ortega of Nicaragua, center, in Managua, the country’s capital, in February last year.

item.title: Israel Security Chief Warns Against Incitement of Conflict as Tensions Mount Before Key Vote
item.description: The director of the Shin Bet, Nadav Argaman, made a rare public appeal amid fears that a new round of turmoil might disrupt attempts to form a new government.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Israel security forces fired a stun grenade at a protest in East Jerusalem in support of a pair of Palestinian activists who were detained on Sunday.

item.title: Mississippi Governor Says Don't Worry About State's Low Vaccine Rate
item.description: Gov. Tate Reeves of Mississippi said that there was no longer a high risk of contracting or being hospitalized with Covid-19.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Rory Doyle for The New York Times
item.media:description: Administrators operating a drive through vaccine site on the campus of Delta State University in Cleveland, Miss., in March.

item.title: Graeme Ferguson, Filmmaker Who Helped Create Imax, Dies at 91
item.description: He partnered with friends to produce stunning original technology that would give movie viewers an immersive, stadium-like experience.
item.dc:creator: Alex Vadukul

item.title: Harry and Meghan Announce Birth of Second Baby, Lilibet Diana
item.description: The name pays tribute to Harry’s mother, Diana, Princess of Wales, and grandmother, Queen Elizabeth II, after a year of estrangement between the couple and the royal family.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, and Prince Harry in South Africa in 2019.

item.title: Cholera ‘Forever Destroyed’ U.N.’s Image in Haiti, Ban Ki-moon Says
item.description: In a memoir, the former secretary general said the United Nations should have done far more to combat a cholera scourge traced to peacekeepers. But he also criticized Haitian leaders and the lawyers who sued him.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cholera patients at a clinic in Rendel, Haiti, in 2016.

item.title: Wedding Receptions Are Back, and Italy’s Candy Makers Are Delighted
item.description: The sugarcoated almond confections known as confetti are the favorite of brides but also of the Vatican.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Confetti Pelino candy factory in Sulmona, Italy.

item.title: The Rush to Vaccinate the World Stalls as Funds, Doses Fall Short
item.description: Billion-dollar pledges — and the news that the United States will distribute an initial 25 million doses — will do little to curb the explosive outbreaks in poor countries, experts said
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez and Andrés R. Martínez
item.media:description: Relatives of a man who died of Covid-19 at his burial in Lima, Peru, on Tuesday.

item.title: In Peru Election, Left and Right Clash, With an Economic Model at Stake
item.description: A leftist former schoolteacher with no governing experience and the right-wing daughter of a jailed ex-president faced off for president on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Mitra Taj and Julie Turkewitz
item.media:description: A contentious political rally in Lima, Peru. The candidates have framed the vote as a fundamental choice over the country’s economic future.

item.title: We’ll Probably Need Booster Shots for Covid-19. But When? And Which Ones?
item.description: Scientists are asking a lot of questions about Covid-19 booster shots, but they don’t yet have many answers. Here’s what they know so far.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:credit: Brett Carlsen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A vial of the Pfizer vaccine at a clinic in Nashville last month. “We’re in uncharted waters here in terms of boosters,” one doctor said.

item.title: Israeli Ultra-Orthodox Excluded From Coalition, Face Loss of Power
item.description: A new coalition that aims to remove Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu from office could also usher in a more liberal civil rights agenda.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: Ultra-Orthodox Jewish men voting in Israel’s parliamentary election in March.

item.title: Kamala Harris in Guatemala Faces a Stark Reality About Migration
item.description: A stark reality faces the vice president as she visits the region: Expanded aid programs have failed to stem migration.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff, Michael D. Shear and Daniele Volpe
item.media:description: A coffee farmer at work in San Antonio Huista, Guatemala.

item.title: Biden Is Embracing Europe, but Then What? NATO and the E.U. Have Concerns.
item.description: After the Trump trauma, Europe will welcome Biden’s warm words, but tough topics remain, from China and Russia to trade disputes, Covid-19 vaccine diplomacy and transitions to carbon-neutral economies.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Oliver Contreras for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden’s trip to Europe for meetings with the Group of 7, NATO, the European Union and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia will be more than symbolic.

item.title: Amsterdam Works to Shore Up Its Crumbling Canals and Bridges
item.description: For the next two decades, the scenic city and tourist magnet is going to look more like one gigantic construction site.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Erdbrink
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.media:description: Construction workers rebuilding the crumbling canal wall in the Grimburgwal district of Amsterdam.
